name: Never use PS and VP1 login to develop - Component (PeopleSoft)
associatedValueName: Name of the Development Login used for the last update
description: Identify each object that has been modified with the login PS or VP1
output:
This report lists all the Components last updated with PS or VP1 login.
It provides the following information: 
- Component full name.
- The associated value is the name of the Development Login.
rationale:
The delivered PeopleSoft logins, such as PS, VP1, should not be used to develop. Using these default logins defeats the purpose of tracing and thus it disables to possibility to identify the real committer.
Any violation to this principle disable the possibility to precisely identify the author of unwanted code or eventually of malicous code.
reference: Securing Your PeopleSoft Application Environment (PeopleSoft Red Paper Series)
remediation: A specific login has to be created and used to identify precisely who has modified the object.
alternativeName: Never use PS and VP1 login to develop - Component (PeopleSoft)

qualityStandards.name: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges
qualityStandards.description: The software performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

qualityStandards.name: Security Misconfiguration
qualityStandards.description: Good security requires having a secure configuration defined and deployed for the application, frameworks, application server, web server, database server, and platform. Secure settings should be defined, implemented, and maintained, as defaults are often insecure. Additionally, software should be kept up to date.

qualityStandards.name: Security Misconfiguration
qualityStandards.description: Security misconfiguration is the most commonly seen issue. This is commonly a result of insecure default configurations, incomplete or ad hoc configurations, open cloud storage, misconfigured HTTP headers, and verbose error messages containing sensitive information. Not only must all operating systems, frameworks, libraries, and applications be securely configured, but they must be patched/upgraded in a timely fashion.

qualityStandards.name: Remove development, test and/or custom application accounts, user IDs, and passwords before applications become active or are released to customers.
Remove development, test and/or custom application accounts, user IDs, and passwords before applications become active or are released to customers.
Unnecessary built-in application accounts must be disabled.
qualityStandards.description:
Default passwords and properties of built-in accounts are often publicly available. Anyone with necessary knowledge, internal or external, can compromise an application using built-in accounts.

Built-in accounts are those that are added as part of the installation of the application software. These accounts exist for many common Commercial Off-the-Shelf (COTS) or open source components of enterprise applications (e.g., OS, web browser or database software).
